Why did anyone care to begin with?

They didnâ€™t. Initially Heike Kamerlingh Onnes Delft and Kes (2010) and others were just interested in cryogenics.
Once they achieved liquid Helium, they asked why note study conductive metals at these temperatures.
In 1911 Kamerlingh Onnes started with elemental Mercury, ðŸ’¥ the field of superconductivity (SC) was born.

Physcist focused on measurement of other elemental solides and a theory.
Observation of SC in Nb is really what begun technological use.





FigureÂ 1: Original plot of Hg transition temperature to SC phase Delft and Kes (2010).






SC: Superconductivity. Nb: Niobium

Superconducting coils allow for high magnetic fields need to image nuclear resoance in human body.

Some Comments






Important


These are working notes, so there are bound to be errors. Please keep this in mind while going through the notes. Feel free to email me if you want to provide corrections.









Note


Much of the notes derived from various sources, please checkout the references.









Tip


If you prefer to view this in a report format, you can download a formatted PDF of this presentation here.

title: Crash Course in Materials Science of Superconductors
text:
Whats all the fuss



Why did anyone care to begin with?

They didnâ€™t. Initially Heike Kamerlingh Onnes1 and others were just interested in cryogenics.
Once they achieved liquid Helium, they asked why note study conductive metals at these temperatures.
In 1911 Kamerlingh Onnes started with elemental Mercury, ðŸ’¥ the field of superconductivity (SC) was born.

Physcist focused on measurement of other elemental solides and a theory.
Observation of SC in Nb is really what begun technological use.





FigureÂ 1: Original plot of Hg transition temperature to SC phase1.






SC: Superconductivity. Nb: Niobium

title: Crash Course in Materials Science of Superconductors
text:
References


1. Delft, D. van & Kes, P. The discovery of superconductivity. Physics Today 63, 38â€“43 (2010).


2. Wang, Q. L., Dai, Y. M., Zhao, B., Song, S. S., Wang, C. Q., Li, L., Cheng, J., Chen, S., Wang, H., Ni, Z., Li, Y., Cui, C., Hu, X., Lei, Y., Chan, K., Yan, L., Wen, C., Hui, G., Yang, W. C., Liu, F., Zhuo, Y., Zhou, X., Yan, Z., Chen, J. & Xu, T. A superconducting magnet system for whole-body metabolism imaging. IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity 22, 4400905â€“4400905 (2012).


3. Nishijima, S., Eckroad, S., Marian, A., Choi, K., Kim, W. S., Terai, M., Deng, Z., Zheng, J., Wang, J., Umemoto, K., Du, J., Febvre, P., Keenan, S., Mukhanov, O., Cooley, L. D., Foley, C. P., Hassenzahl, W. V. & Izumi, M. Superconductivity and the environment: A roadmap. Superconductor Science and Technology 26, 113001 (2013).


4. Speller, S. A materials science guide to superconductors and how to make them super. (Oxford University Press, 2022).

  author = {Bringuier, Stefan},
  date = {2023-09-14},
  url = {https://stefanbringuier.github.io/CrashCourseSCMaterials//slides/basic_theory.html},
  langid = {en},
  abstract = {This document provides basic review of superconducting
    materials from a materials science \textbackslash\& engineering
    perspective. This entails a very basic review of conductivity,
    magnetism, and superconductivity theory. The remainder is focused on
    aspects of specific material systems, such as compositional phases
    that exhibit superconducting phase, mechanical properties, and
    processing. High-level review of applications is also provided. The
    intent of this document is to act as a quick digest for someone who
    plans to dive deeper into the provided references.}
}
